0.Event: Ruy Lopez: Closed: The Ruy Lopez Pawn Structure
0.pgnContent:
1... c5 { This pawn structure almost always stems from the Ruy Lopez opening.
White's possible plans are to advance d4-d5 and later c3-c4, transposing into a King's Indian Structure under favorable circumstances.
Black can respond with c5-c4 which will be covered most famously with Karpov-Unzicker 1974.
White can also capture e5 or c5 and transpose into a King's Indian structure.
If Black captures e5xe4, white can still play d4-d6 and turn the position into a Benoni.
Black can capture c5xd4 and turn the position into a King's Indian structure. } 2. Kf1 *

1.pgnContent:
1... e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 d6 8. c3 O-O { White needs to prevent the annoying Bg4 and limit black's activity. } 9. h3 Na5 10. Bc2 c5 { Also known as the Chigorin Defense for black. } 11. d4 Qc7 12. Nbd2 Nc6 { Transform the position into a closed Ruy Lopez pawn formation.
White's plans are to open the a file with a4, but also create a kingside attack with an eventual f4-f5 and focus on maneuvering the knights. } 13. d5 { [%cal Gc6b8] } 13... Nd8 { The knight to d8 clogs up all of black's pieces and limits the knights activity. Better is Nb8. } 14. a4 Rb8 15. axb5 axb5 16. b4 { Shutting down the last rook move by black. If black captures the b pawn and opens the position a little, it exposes the weakness of black's side. Most importantly the b5 pawn that white can exploit. } 16... Nb7 17. Nf1 Bd7 18. Be3 Ra8 19. Qd2 Rfc8 { Black is threatening to open the c file and win a piece or a pawn. } { [%cal Gc7c2] } 20. Bd3 g6 21. Ng3 Bf8 22. Ra2 c4 { Black has now locked down the pawns and thus all counterplay and activity is solely on the kingside.
The bishop needs to move, but it still needs to keep an eye on f5 to prevent a possible pawn break and opening of the position for black. } { [%csl Gf5] } 23. Bb1 Qd8 { Find the killer move that completely locks in the position.
The thought process is a blockade in which black cannot maintain control of the A file nor make use of his own dark-squared bishop. } 24. Ba7 Ne8 { Karpov completely controls the A file.
The center is closed and there's no way to help attack the bishop on a7, where it remains the entire game. } 25. Bc2 Nc7 26. Rea1 Qe7 { Black has no activity and can only wait to see what black does. } { [%csl Gf5] } 27. Bb1 Be8 28. Ne2 Nd8 29. Nh2 Bg7 30. f4 f6 (30... exf4 31. Nxf4 Bh6 32. Nxg6 Bxd2 33. Nxe7+) 31. f5 g5 { Karpov controls the only open file and has a locked-down position. The only step next is to take advantage of the light squares since black's pawns on the kingside are almost all on dark squares.
Karpov's plans are to play on the light squares and avoid moving any more pawns on the kingside. } { [%csl Gb4,Gc3,Gd5,Ge4,Gf5][%cal Gb1c2,Gc2d1,Gd1h5] } 32. Bc2 Bf7 33. Ng3 Nb7 34. Bd1 h6 { Black has given up on trying to open the position and is hoping white cannot do anything more than hope for a draw.
Black's dark-squared bishop can do nothing in this game anymore.
Black's light-squared bishop is the best defender, so Karpov works to trade it off. } { [%csl Gg7] } 35. Bh5 Qe8 36. Qd1 Nd8 { The next few moves are close to the 40 moves to meet time control. Karpov is able to simply wait a few moves and waste time, only slightly improving his pieces. } 37. Ra3 Kf8 38. R1a2 Kg8 39. Ng4 Kf8 { Tactically, black cannot capture the bishop on h5. } (39... Bxh5 40. Nxh5 Qxh5 41. Nxf6+ Bxf6 42. Qxh5) 40. Ne3 Kg8 41. Bxf7+ Nxf7 42. Qh5 Nd8 { It may seem weird to offer a trade of queens, but Karpov wants to bring the knights in to f5 and build more pressure on the backwards pawns on d6 and h6. } 43. Qg6 Kf8 (43... Qxg6 44. fxg6 { [%csl Gg7][%cal Gg3h5,Ge3f5,Gf5h6] } 44... Ne8 45. Nef5 Bf8 46. Ra5 Nc7 47. Bb6 Rxa5 48. Rxa5 Ne8 49. Ra7 Rb8 50. Rd7 Nb7 51. Ba7 Nd8 52. Bxb8) 44. Nh5 { 1-0 Black resigns. } 1-0

2.pgnContent:
1... Nc6 2. e4 e5 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 d6 8. c3 O-O 9. h3 Na5 10. Bc2 c5 11. d4 Qc7 { White chooses to close the center and avoid theory. } 12. d5 c4 { This is a mistake and a premature pawn move that ends up being black's downfall this game.. Black should simply develop with Bd7.
The next move forces black to give up active play on the queenside.
White's plans on the queenside are simply beautiful in this game thanks to the space advantage afforded by the move d5. } 13. b4 cxb3 14. axb3 Bd7 15. Ba3 { [%cal Gf3e5] } 15... Bd8 { White was threatening Nxe5 with an x-ray on the bishop on d7, winning a pawn. } (15... Rfe8 16. Nxe5 dxe5 17. Bxe7 Rxe7 18. d6) 16. Bd3 Nb7 { With the knight retreating, it's important to stop any queenside counter play and keep the knight from c5. The dark-squared bishop has done its job on the a3-f8 diagonal and white can close the diagonal now. } 17. b4 Be7 18. Bc1 Rfc8 { Similar to the Karpov game, we want to double our rooks on the A file. The simplest way is Re2-A2. } 19. Re2 a5 20. Rea2 Qd8 21. Be3 axb4 { We mentioned in the last lesson that capturing on b4 would weaken the b5 pawn. This game further shows how true that point is. } { [%csl Gb5] } 22. cxb4 Rxa2 23. Rxa2 Ra8 24. Qe2 g6 25. Nc3 Rxa2 26. Qxa2 Qc7 27. Nxb5 Bxb5 28. Bxb5 Nxe4 29. Qa7 { 1-0 Black resigns. } 1-0

3.pgnContent: 1... e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 d6 8. c3 O-O 9. h3 Na5 10. Bc2 c5 11. d4 Qc7 12. d5 Bd7 13. b3 c4 14. Ba3 Bd8 15. Nbd2 Ne8 16. Bb4 cxb3 17. axb3 Nb7 18. Qe2 Qb8 19. Ba3 Bb6 20. b4 Nc7 21. Bd3 a5 22. Nf1 axb4 23. cxb4 f6 24. Ne3 g6 25. Bb2 Rxa1 26. Rxa1 Nd8 27. Nd2 Nf7 28. Kh2 Qd8 29. Rf1 Qe7 30. Bc1 Ra8 31. Nb1 Bd4 32. Nc2 Bb6 33. Nc3 f5 34. exf5 gxf5 35. f4 Rc8 36. Be3 Bxe3 37. Qxe3 Ne8 38. Be2 Qf6 39. Qd2 exf4 40. Nd4 Qe5 41. Bxb5 f3+ 42. Kg1 Bxb5 43. Ncxb5 fxg2 44. Rxf5 Qe4 45. Nc3 Qh4 46. Qxg2+ Kh8 47. Nce2 Nf6 48. Rf4 Qh6 49. Nf5 Qf8 50. Ned4 Ne5 51. b5 Qg8 52. Ne7 Rc1+ 53. Kh2 Qxg2+ 54. Kxg2 Nfd7 55. Ndf5 Nc4 56. Rg4 Nf6 57. Rg3 Rc2+ 58. Kg1 Rc1+ 59. Kh2 Rc2+ 60. Rg2 Rxg2+ 61. Kxg2 Ne4 62. Nc8 Nc3 63. Ncxd6 Nb6 64. Ne3 Kg7 65. Kf3 Kf8 66. Kf4 Ke7 67. Ndc4 Nxc4 68. Nxc4 Nxd5+ 69. Kg5 Kd7 70. h4 Ne7 71. Kf6 Ng6 72. Ne5+ Nxe5 73. Kxe5 Kc7 74. h5 Kb6 75. Kf6 Kxb5 76. Kg7 Ka4 77. Kxh7 Kb3 78. h6 Ka2 79. Kg6 Kb1 80. h7 Kc2 81. h8=Q { 1-0 White wins. } 1-0

4.Opening: Ruy Lopez: Morphy Defense, Steinitz Deferred
4.pgnContent:
1... e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 d6 5. O-O Nf6 6. Re1 Bd7 7. c3 g6 8. d4 b5 9. Bb3 Bg7 10. Bg5 { This is the beginning of a bad plan for white. Better is h3 and continuing on the main lines. } 10... O-O 11. Nbd2 Re8 12. h3 h6 13. Bh4 { The dark-squared bishop is not well placed on h4 and is better on c1. } 13... Na5 14. Bc2 { Black is more well prepared than previous games for a closed Ruy Lopez formation. Playing c5 now, black will not have the slow suffocation that was seen in Karpov v Unzicker.
After Qc7, the pin is lifted and the dark-squared bishop is doing nothing on h4.
This game shows what black can expect after capturing on d4 with both the e5 and c5 pawns. The d6 pawn will be backwards, but the question is whether or not black's piece will have more activity or not. } 14... c5 15. Nb3 cxd4 16. Nxa5 Qxa5 17. cxd4 { Black can now open the position and the long diagonal. Black has much better piece activity in this game. White's pieces are uncoordinated. } 17... exd4 18. Nxd4 Qb6 19. Nf3 { White should have a long term strength thanks to the backwards and isolated d6 pawn.
Since black's pieces are better coordinated and can take advantage of the position sooner rather than waiting around for white to find coordination.
Black's bishop has the open long diagonal and white's bishop is useless on h4 still. } 19... Be6 20. Nd4 { Black can remaneuver the light-squared bishop to b7 where it hits the weakened e4 pawn. } 20... Bc8 { [%cal Gc8b7] } 21. Qd2 Bb7 22. Bxf6 Bxf6 23. Rad1 { Black can now toss away the weak d6 pawn and completely open the board up for the amazing bishop pair. } 23... d5 24. Bb3 (24. exd5 Rxe1+ 25. Rxe1 Bxd4) 24... Rxe4 25. Rxe4 dxe4 26. Nf5 Rd8 27. Nxh6+ Kg7 28. Qc1 Rxd1+ 29. Bxd1 e3 30. Ng4 exf2+ 31. Kf1 Bd4 32. Qh6+ Kg8 33. Qf4 Qc6 34. Bf3 Qc4+ 35. Be2 Bxg2+ 36. Kxg2 Qxe2 37. Nh6+ Kh7 { 0-1 White resigns. } 0-1
